Award.AwardTitle: Structures of Long-Term Disaster Recovery: Organizational Roles and Collaboration in Six Cities

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Long-term recovery is the least theorized and studied stage of disasters. Yet, in the past decade, large disasters such as Hurricanes Katrina (2005), Rita (2005), Ike (2008), and Sandy (2012), and smaller but still destructive disasters such as wildfires in Texas (2011) and Colorado (2013), flooding of the Mississippi River (2011), and even technological disasters (West, TX 2013) have left numerous communities struggling with post-disaster planning, unequal and partial recovery outcomes, and recovery efforts that fail to reduce pre-disaster vulnerabilities. Increasing disaster frequencies and impacts mean more communities will struggle, often with little local experience in managing the difficult processes of achieving sustainable and resilient recovery. This research focuses on disaster recovery across different communities to build the knowledge-base and best practices that will help other communities prepare for and plan for disaster recovery. The results of this research will support efforts by local governments and nongovernmental organizations to develop recovery frameworks and plans that will speed disaster recovery and improve fiscal efficiency.

To accomplish these goals, this research project involves in-depth study and extensive comparative analysis of the structures and networks of groups and organizations involved in disaster recovery efforts across six different communities that recently experienced disasters: Granbury, Texas (2013, tornado), West, Texas (2013, industrial facility explosion), Marion County, Texas (2011, wildfire), Bastrop County, Texas (2011, wildfire), Galveston, Texas (2008, Hurricane Ike), Brownsville, Texas (2008, Hurricane Dolly). Governmental and nongovernmental collaboration during recovery is important, yet which types of collaboration work best for recovery are little understood. Most disaster-related studies on organizational collaboration focus on response and emergency management agencies not on charities and community organizations that work on long-term recovery for two to ten years following a disaster. For each of the case locations, the researchers will conduct in-person interviews with organizational leaders, observe recovery committee and community meetings, document recovery events, and analyze community reconstruction and rehabilitation. This approach will provide rich information that will enable the team to compare and contrast the practices used in the different cases and develop a model of disaster recovery organizational networks. This data will allow the researchers to evaluate the organizational coordination in disaster recovery and describe interactions between various levels of government (local, regional, state, and national). Based on the project outcomes, the researchers will identify promising practices and lessons learned which can be utilized by other communities that are engaged in pre-disaster or post-disaster recovery planning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Disasters give rise to a variety of social and organizational responses, from coordination by trained emergency management whose missions focus on disasters to untrained emergent groups improvising to fulfill disaster needs. As early disaster research documented, only some of the organizations that respond in crisis have trained in many of the tasks they conduct, while other organizational responses involve groups that often lack education and training about disaster processes. These organizations will nevertheless undertake tasks outside their routine operations (extending organizations) and even develop new organizational structures following a disaster (emergent organizations). For example, local nonprofit organizations (NPOs) such as food pantries, homeless shelters, domestic violence centers, and religious institutions may extend their operations into new areas that tackle disaster needs of their local community or clients. Emergent organizations, such as neighborhood search-and-rescue crews, long-term recovery organizations, or networks of local financial experts forge new organizational structures during an emergency and take on tasks outside their usual community roles. Leaders in these extending and emergent organizations often lack disaster-specific training and thus develop protocols and tactics, for better or worse, during the disaster situation.

Our 4-year project collected over interviews with over 70 recovery professionals and involved observation at local meetings in 7 disaster affected communities to understand how local and regional organizational leaders collaborated and coordinated to meet disaster recovery needs of their fellow community members. We found that many organizations assumed that FEMA or private insurance would cover most disaster recovery needs, which is not the case as those resources are often limited or inaccessible to many affected residents.

We found that communities undertake one of two models to coordinate to meet these "unmet needs" of disaster survivors: start a new 501(c)3 nonprofit organization focused on recovery or develop a network of nonprofits to address recovery needs. 

Once formed these "long-term recovery teams" have several key tasks: determine who qualifies for recovery aid; determine what items or needs qualify for recovery aid; determine a priority system for needs and qualified persons; find qualified people to fulfill needed tasks; determine how to communicate with the public and the media. 

Several aspects improve long-term recovery team operation: local leadership, public participation of survivors, participation from multiple organizations, diversity of long-term recovery team leadership, regular meeting and communication, and participation of experts (e.g. housing, case management, disaster recovery, legal, donation management, construction, land management, financial, knowledge of affected population, spiritual care, mental and physical health care, and connection to government resources). 

Long-term recovery teams were able to become operational and address needs quicker if they were formed pre-disaster. The next fastest formation involved using existing networks of nonprofits as a springboard for recovery (for example a group of nonprofits that address housing needs could change focus to address recovery). Teams that kept the network active or the 501(c)3 open were able to more quickly respond to another disaster - improving resilience for the community. 

Key challenges for long-term recovery teams was burn-out of key staff or volunteers, too many physical donations (e.g., furniture and clothing), lack of financial resources to finish all recovery tasks and address all needs, difficulty gathering volunteers and financial resources later in the recovery process (6 months - 2 years after the disaster). 

All participants wished they had better prepared for recovery not just disaster response before the disaster affected their community. 

This project involved 9 graduate students and 8 undergraduate students in research activities. Of those 9 graduate students, 8 were from groups commonly underrepresented in science. Of the 8 undergraduate students, 6 were from groups commonly underrepresented in science.
